How can I print a pandas dataframe in Python as a nicely formatted text-based table, similar to the one below?

```
+------------+---------+-------------+
| column_one | col_two |   column_3  |
+------------+---------+-------------+
|          0 |  0.0001 | ABCD        |
|          1 |  1e-005 | ABCD        |
|          2 |  1e-006 | long string |
|          3 |  1e-007 | ABCD        |
+------------+---------+-------------+
```

To print a Pandas DataFrame as a nicely formatted text-based table, you can use the `tabulate` library in Python. This library provides an easy way to create tables with different styles, including plain text, grid, and more. Below is an example of how you can achieve this:

1. First, you need to install the `tabulate` library if you haven't already. You can do this using pip:

   ```bash
   pip install tabulate
   ```

2. Once installed, you can use the following code to print your DataFrame in a grid format:

   ```python
   import pandas as pd
   from tabulate import tabulate

   # Create a sample DataFrame
   data = {
       'column_one': [0, 1, 2, 3],
       'col_two': [0.0001, 1e-5, 1e-6, 1e-7],
       'column_3': ['ABCD', 'ABCD', 'long string', 'ABCD']
   }

   df = pd.DataFrame(data)

   # Use tabulate to format the DataFrame
   print(tabulate(df, headers='keys', tablefmt='grid'))
   ```

3. This will output the DataFrame in a grid format similar to the one you provided:

   ```
   +--------------+----------+--------------+
   |   column_one |   col_two | column_3     |
   +==============+==========+==============+
   |            0 |   0.0001  | ABCD         |
   +--------------+----------+--------------+
   |            1 |   1e-05   | ABCD         |
   +--------------+----------+--------------+
   |            2 |   1e-06   | long string  |
   +--------------+----------+--------------+
   |            3 |   1e-07   | ABCD         |
   +--------------+----------+--------------+
   ```

By using `tabulate`, you can easily change the `tablefmt` parameter to other styles like 'plain', 'pipe', 'html', etc., to suit your needs.
